title: Wound Closure Classification
description: Classifies wound closure types to guide surgical management strategies. Stratifies wounds based on contamination level, tissue loss, and time since injury to recommend appropriate closure method (primary, secondary, or tertiary closure).

parameters.name: contamination_level
parameters.description: Level of wound contamination affecting infection risk

parameters.name: tissue_loss
parameters.description: Extent of tissue loss affecting ability to achieve tension-free closure

parameters.name: time_since_injury
parameters.description: Time elapsed since injury in hours

parameters.name: vascularization
parameters.description: Wound bed vascularization status affecting healing potential

parameters.name: wound_location
parameters.description: Anatomical location of the wound affecting closure options

ranges.interpretation: Clean wound with minimal tissue loss suitable for immediate closure. Close within 6-8 hours ideally, up to 24 hours if well-vascularized.
Significant tissue loss preventing tension-free closure. Leave open to heal by granulation tissue and wound contraction with daily dressing changes.
Contaminated wound requiring thorough debridement. Observe for 3-7 days before surgical closure or skin grafting to minimize infection risk.

references: Hollander JE, Singer AJ. Laceration management. Ann Emerg Med. 1999;34(3):356-367. doi: 10.1016/s0196-0644(99)70131-9
Singer AJ, Hollander JE, Quinn JV. Evaluation and management of traumatic lacerations. N Engl J Med. 1997;337(16):1142-1148. doi: 10.1056/NEJM199710163371607
Forsch RT. Essentials of skin laceration repair. Am Fam Physician. 2008;78(8):945-951
Quinn J, Wells G, Sutcliffe T, et al. A randomized trial comparing octylcyanoacrylate tissue adhesive and sutures in the management of lacerations. JAMA. 1997;277(19):1527-1530
formula: Classification based on contamination level, tissue loss, time since injury, vascularization, and anatomical location
notes: Surgeon experience and clinical judgment are critical in wound closure decisions
Patient-specific factors (comorbidities, medications, nutritional status) influence healing
Consider tetanus prophylaxis for contaminated wounds
Antibiotic prophylaxis may be indicated for high-risk wounds
Limited application in abdominal and orthopedic wounds
